body: @ijuma fair point. But there may be some other scenarios where admins want full control on topic creation and ACLs related to to those topics.  I don't have any strong use case. If others also thinks the same, we can close this JIRA.

> It makes me a bit uneasy just dropping the null records as it might mask bugs in user code

The reason we changed aggregation logic to ignore null keys (it was raising exception as well before) was discussed here: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1472#discussion-diff-66519952

Thinking about it a bit more, I feel the rationale back then was not very thoughtful: if aggregation is following a repartition, then it should not expect any null keys, as otherwise repartitioning would make no sense; but it could also be not following a repartition, in which case it could happen to see null keys. So I agree with you about making the behavior to be "throwing exception" as the default behavior, but currently since we do not have any finer grained exception handler, this would mean that the error will be thrown all the way out of the instance, where users already have limited options but to close the whole instance.

So from an operability perspective, I'd suggest 1) for now we still ignore the record for both join and aggregation, and log a warning when doing so, 2) add the dropping record metrics as a followup; 3) when we add the finer exception handling mechanism, change the "global default" behavior back to throw exception, which could be caught at the operator level and users can then react more efficiently. WDYT?

Fair enough On Thu, 26 Jan 2017 at 21:40, Matthias J. Sax wrote: > *@mjsax* commented on this pull request. > ------------------------------ > > In streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KTable.java > : > > > - * > - * @param selector select the grouping key and value to be aggregated > - * @param keySerde key serdes for materializing this stream, > - * if not specified the default serdes defined in the configs will be used > - * @param valueSerde value serdes for materializing this stream, > - * if not specified the default serdes defined in the configs will be used > - * @param the key type of the {@link KGroupedTable} > - * @param the value type of the {@link KGroupedTable} > - * > - * @return a {@link KGroupedTable} that contains the re-partitioned records of this {@link KTable} > + * Join records of this {@link KTable} with another {@link KTable}'s records using non-windowed inner equi join. > + * The join is a primary key join with join attribute {@code thisKTable.key == otherKTable.key}. > + * The result is an ever updating {@link KTable} that represents the current (i.e., processing time) result > + * of the join. > + *

> + * The join is computed by (1) updating the internal state if one {@link KTable} and (2) performing a lookup for a > > Why? > To my knowledge, for two things that are listed there is no comma: "A and > B" > Only for three or more, there are command: "A, B, C, and D" > > Correct my if I am wrong. > > — > You are receiving this because you were mentioned. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > , or mute the thread > > . >

> This already happens. The test shouldAssignMoreTasksToClientWithMoreCapacity shows this.
> @mjsax was referring to having more tasks. I'll expand the test and see what i can come up with

I think we are talking about the same, that when all clients are over-capacity already, should the num.tasks be proportional to client's total capacity, and from the tests it seems the case.
